properties.name: 's Warm
properties.description: Posted by Tooldivaa swarm of over 1000 lovebugs by Hilary Pfeifer March 1 through June 18th, 2006 455 Oak Street, Brockton, MA

properties.name: Echo Chamber Sculpture
properties.description: Posted by Hive  Laurelhurst Park, NE Portland, ORA large steel sculpture that is a natural echo box. In fact, once i strapped a custom backless guitar to this thing so that IT became the sound box of the guitar. Watch out in summer, it can get hot.

properties.name: Urban Hike
properties.description: Posted by Symplvision   Go to this place and try a 10 mile urban hike. You can read about this project on my web site. It\'s 30 laps around the block. Look for the paper clips on the chain link fence. These mark the number of laps. Bring your own though! After you do this, email me with pics, writing, scans, songs, or whatever you want to document your experience. I predict you will have a meditative journey, and you will be surprised by what happens. Thanks

properties.name: Voodoo Doughnuts
properties.description: Posted by Jason     22 SW 3rd Ave, portland, orCocoa Puff doughnuts, voodoo doll doughnuts, cock&balls doughnuts. Only open in the middle of hte night, 10pm - 10am. Mostly organic locally grown ingredients too! OOh, they have eating contests, bands play there etc. http://www.voodoodoughnut.com/

properties.name: a pretty cool dog park
properties.description: Posted by Tooldiva  My dog is an avid squirrel chaser, so I prefer to bring her to a dog park that is fenced so she can have the experience of running as free as the wind. Such is the urban pooch experience. Normandale Park is great because it\'s pretty big, has lots of trees, and isn\'t a former toxic waste dump like the fenced dog areas at Delta Park and Gabriel Park. I have also met a few very nice humans in my time at Normandale who are courteous and responsible with their pets, as well as being good conversationalists. Portland still has yet to have a really great dog park like the one in Ashland or the Dr. Jose Rizal Park in Seattle. But for the time being, this one does quite well.

properties.name: a pretty great dog park
properties.description: Posted by Tooldiva  If you\'re stuck in Ashland with your dog, this is a great place to pass the time. If it\'s summer, you\'re in luck - there\'s a wading pool just for your dog! Otherwise, it\'s pretty cool - a picnic table under a tree, tennis balls with rackets for hitting them in the huge 2 acre grassy field. What more could a dog ask for, really? (Well, maybe the Dr. Jose Rizal Dog Park in Seattle, but that\'s a different story.) I don\'t know if I got the exact location pinpointed on the Platial map, so you\'d be wise to consult another source before trying to find it on your own. It\'s behind some greenhouses, as I recall.

properties.name: a really cool dog park
properties.description: Posted by Tooldiva  This is a fantastic dog park. It\'s good for the dogs because they can run way way out of the range of their owners and have less of a chance of being called back because the owner knows that they are fenced in and secure. But it\'s great for the owners because it\'s got a spectacular view of Seattle, as well as having a 9.5 acre area to walk on the trails that run throughout. A word of warning: I followed the directions on the city\'s website to this park, and there was a "right" turn when it should have been a "left" turn early in the directions. Somehow we were able to figure this out, and I don\'t know if they\'ve corrected it in the past 2 years, but be warned!

properties.name: art 4 dogs
properties.description: Posted by Tooldiva I might not have the exact location pinpointed on the map, but this is a piece of public art commissioned by a private group a few years ago. It\'s by the artist William Wegman, better known for his portraits of Weimeraners in human clothing. It\'s not prominent, but if you look, you will find it. There\'s a patch of black and white granite tiles (with a little turf mixed in) meant to evoke a linoleum tile kitchen floor. Inside this area is a dog bowl that was originally intended to be perpetually refilled with water, like a little fountain. (It was inspired by the Benson Bubblers.) I haven\'t been by in a while, but I remember that there was some controversy for a while about the city paying the water bill so it was shut off. I\'m sure someone on Platial will be able to comment on the current status of the water. Hello? Anyone know?

properties.name: more everyday sunshine
properties.description: Posted by TooldivaThis is as good a place as any to start discovering one of Portland\'s most conceptual public art projects. Along the entire length of the streetcar line, there are fourteen motion-sensored spotlights that are triggered by pedestrians walking along the sidewalk. You must be on the same side of the street and walking in the same direction as the streetcar runs. The spotlights are attached to utility poles. The light won\'t come on immediately - sometimes it takes several minutes for it to fade on and slowly fade off. The spotlights illuminate things you might not normally think too much about, like a simple architectural feature, a park bench, or a patch of dirt. When I first heard Harrell Fletcher describe his concept for the project, it went something like this: "When I was a boy, my father and I would go on walks and he would point at things that he thought were interesting. Later in my life, I studied photography, and I thought of that as a form of pointing, or saying "I find this interesting." The spotlights are intended to illuminate things that I found interesting along the streetcar line." This public art piece makes a really fun evening walk for the curious.

properties.name: the place where I first kissed a boy and also where I first kissed a girl
properties.description: Posted by Tooldiva I think it\'s now called "Agate Hall" but when I was in 5th grade, it was still a school. It was Condon School. I was in an "arranged" relationship which was announced to me in a phone call by a classmate who basically explained to me that I was now with her old boyfriend Kevin, so she could go out with Todd. I guess I said okay. A few weeks or so later, I was told by my friend that Kevin was going to kiss me after school. A bunch of other students were hanging around - I guess they\'d heard the news too. Finally everyone left except me and Kevin. We were at the bottom of one of the stairwells of the building. He leaned over to kiss me and I turned my head, thinking he would kiss my cheek. This made him kiss the air because he was aiming for my mouth. We were both embarassed. He hit the mark the next time. Fifteen years later, I was on my first date with a woman in the same building, which was now turned into a performance space. I brought her to the same place and bravely told her the story I just shared with you. The rest is history. But I\'ll tell you, the second first kiss in that spot was MUCH better than the first first one.

properties.name: the wave organ
properties.description: Posted by Tooldiva  San FranciscoThe wave organ was built as a project for the exploratorium in San Francisco. It\'s an amphitheater on the shore of the San Francisco bay. The seats are made from recycled city cement from demolished curbs or graveyard stones. The sound is provided by the bay - tubes extend from underwater to the amphitheater. If you sit very quietly, a sloshing symphony will fill your ears. I hear the best time to experience it is early in the morning. To find the wave organ, follow the shoreline north of the exploratorium. You will come to a marina, and you walk out on a little piece of land - it looks like you\'re just going to a yacht club, (it\'s near Yacht Road, in fact) but you will have to trust and when you see a yellow diamond sign that says "not a through street" you are getting close.

properties.name: tiny noises
properties.description: Posted by TooldivaThis is one of many Benson Bubblers in Portland. The story goes that Simon Benson, A developer in Portland around the early 1900\'s put in around 25 of these drinking fountains around town so his workers wouldn\'t drink alcohol in the middle of the day. They make a really nice bloopy sound if you lean in close on a quiet night.

properties.name: tiny noises
properties.description: Posted by TooldivaIf you stand on the corner outside the Portland Outdoor Store on a quiet night, there is an unusual whistling sound that is made by the motor of this classic neon sign. At the bottom of the sign, there\'s an element that\'s supposed to look like a cattle brand and on one side you can read that it says "the best brands" inside the neon frame. (on the other side the text has worn off.) The sign whistles when the light is off, then it\'s silent when the red branding iron lights up again.

properties.name: tiny noises
properties.description: Posted by Tooldivathere\'s a house between Mason and Skidmore on NE 17th Ave. that has two tiny birch trees in the parking strip. The house is on the west side of 17th Ave. If you lean up close to them on a dry, windy day, you will hear the most delicate sound of the curled papery bark rustling.
